facts.text: Election held in March 1957 for Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Chittorgarh Constituency.
Respondent No. 1 Lal Singh declared duly elected on 11th March 1957 with 7272 votes.
Respondent No. 2 Laxman Singh secured 7261 votes.
Respondent No. 3 Chhoga Lal secured 569 votes.

Appellant, an elector in Chittorgarh Constituency, filed election petition challenging validity of respondent No. 1's election on grounds of corrupt practices: procurement of invalid votes materially affecting result, and publication of false statements (Exts. 3 and 6) relating to personal character or conduct of respondent No. 2.

Election Tribunal framed 26 issues, held allegations of invalid votes not proved, Ext. 3 published by agent of respondent No. 1 but not with express consent, not satisfied Ext. 6 published by his agent; dismissed petition.
Appellant appealed to Rajasthan High Court (D.B. Civil Misc. Election Appeal No. 1 of 1960), judgment dated August 2, 1960.

High Court confirmed Tribunal on invalid votes though dissatisfied with some reasoning; accepted Ext. 3 by agent with consent, reversed on Ext. 6 holding published for benefit of respondent No. 1 with consent; found allegations false and prejudicial but not relating to personal character or conduct of respondent No. 2; dismissed appeal.

Pamphlet Ext. 3 contained statements: 'Enemy of Democracy? Agent of the foreigners strangling the freedom of Bharat? Supporter and collaborator of the conspiracy of Pakistani attack on Bharat? ... Purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of Money? ...' describing respondent No. 2's intentions.
Ext. 6 contained substantially the same portion as Ext. 3.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave; concurrent findings against invalid votes not disputed.
Election in 1957; fresh elections imminent in February 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether the statements in pamphlets Exts. 3 and 6 constitute corrupt practice under s.123(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, by relating to personal character or conduct of respondent No. 2.
Whether respondent No. 2 should be declared duly elected under s.101(b) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent No. 1 procured invalid votes materially affecting result.

Respondent No. 1, agents published false statements (Exts. 3,6) believed false, relating to personal character/conduct of respondent No. 2, prejudicial to his prospects; specifically 'agent of foreigners strangling freedom', 'supporter/collaborator of Pakistani conspiracy', 'purchaser of Congress opponents by money'.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(4) Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Statements, though false, relate to public/political character of respondent No. 2, not personal/private character; distinction must be made.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(4) Representation of the People Act, 1951

court_reasoning.text: s.123(4) requires false statement relating to personal character/conduct or candidature etc., reasonably calculated to prejudice prospects; distinguishes personal/private from public/political character to allow free criticism of latter.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Electorate mature on political issues; protects against false personal attacks.

court_reasoning.text: Borderline cases exist; 'purchaser of opponents of Congress by means of money' implies bribery (moral turpitude), affects private character unequivocally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bribery introduces moral turpitude, affects reputation as individual.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred by general reading without specific consideration of bribery allegation; document read as whole targets respondent No. 2 personally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specific false statement constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(4).

court_reasoning.text: Corrupt practice under s.123(4) falls under s.100(1)(b), not saved by s.100(2); election void; no need to examine other statements.
s.101(b) requires opinion that but for corrupt practices, respondent No. 2 would have majority; not examined by High Court; remand futile due to 1957 election and imminent fresh polls.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No declaration for respondent No. 2; no purpose served.

holdings.text: Publication of false statement in pamphlets that respondent No. 2 is 'purchaser of opponents of Congress by means of money' constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(4) as it relates to personal character.
Election of respondent No. 1 void under s.100(1)(b); no declaration under s.101(b) for respondent No. 2.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (43 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines corrupt practices; grounds for declaring election void; declaration of other candidate duly elected.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; election of respondent No. 1 set aside as void due to corrupt practice under s.123(4); no declaration that respondent No. 2 duly elected due to futility given passage of time since 1957 election and imminent fresh elections.
outcome.relief_granted: Election of respondent No. 1 declared invalid

key_quotes.text: 'Purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of Money?'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Specific false statement held to imply bribery affecting personal character under s.123(4).

key_quotes.text: The provision postulates that if a false statement is made in regard to the public or political character of the candidate, it would not constitute a corrupt practice even if it is likely to prejudice the prospects of that candidate's election.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legislative distinction between personal and public character.

key_quotes.text: Bribery is itself a corrupt practice and if it is said against a candidate that he practices the corrupt practice of buying the votes... that clearly and unequivocally affects his private character.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for finding corrupt practice due to moral turpitude.
